description: Training examples for recovery community moderation AI

examples.content: I really need to find a new source for pills since my guy got arrested
examples.explanation: Clear sourcing request - asking where to obtain substances

examples.content: I'm 30 days sober today! Still going to meetings every day.
examples.explanation: Positive recovery milestone share

examples.content: I want to use so badly right now. I can't stop thinking about it.
examples.explanation: Crisis detected - person reaching out for support. DO NOT remove.

examples.content: If you're not doing AA, you're not really in recovery. You're just fooling yourself.
examples.explanation: Gatekeeping - invalidating non-AA recovery pathways

examples.content: I disagree with how AA approaches spirituality, but I respect that it works for some people.
examples.explanation: Respectful disagreement about program approach - healthy discourse

examples.content: You're such an idiot. No wonder you keep relapsing.
examples.explanation: Direct personal attack with shaming about relapse

examples.content: I hate AA. The whole program is bullshit and I wasted years of my life on it.
examples.explanation: Criticism of a program, not a person - valid frustration

examples.content: Taking Suboxone isn't real sobriety. You're just trading one addiction for another.
examples.explanation: MAT stigma - invalidates medication-assisted treatment as legitimate recovery

examples.content: I saw John Smith from the Tuesday night meeting at the grocery store today!
examples.explanation: Reveals full name of meeting attendee - anonymity violation

examples.content: There's this guy at my home group who always shares for too long. So annoying.
examples.explanation: Vague reference, no identifying info - acceptable venting

examples.content: I don't know if I can make it through tonight. Everything feels pointless.
examples.explanation: Crisis detected - suicidal ideation. Keep visible, rally support.

examples.content: The best way to OD is to mix benzos with opiates. Works every time.
examples.explanation: Explicit self-harm method sharing - dangerous content

examples.content: I finally told my sponsor to back off. He was being way too controlling.
examples.explanation: Working through sponsor relationship - healthy processing

examples.content: You NEED to get a sponsor or you WILL relapse. There's no other way.
examples.explanation: Coercive language removing user agency in their recovery

examples.content: What worked for me was getting a sponsor, but everyone's path is different.
examples.explanation: Sharing experience without prescribing - good crosstalk etiquette

examples.content: Check out my crypto recovery token! Use code SOBER for 10% off!
examples.explanation: Commercial spam exploiting recovery community

examples.content: I relapsed last night. I feel so ashamed. I'm back at day 1.
examples.explanation: Honest share about relapse - exactly what the community is for

examples.content: You relapsed because you didn't work the steps properly. Your sobriety was never real.
examples.explanation: Shaming response to vulnerable relapse disclosure

examples.content: Relapse is part of recovery for many people. You're still here, and that matters.
examples.explanation: Supportive response honoring harm reduction principles

examples.content: Studies show that SMART Recovery has similar outcomes to 12-step programs for many people.
examples.explanation: Factual information about alternative recovery programs

examples.content: Anyone know where the NA meetings are that are chill about people still using?
examples.explanation: Harm reduction approach - person seeking meetings while still using is valid

examples.content: I'm going to use tonight. I've decided. I just wanted to say goodbye to everyone.
examples.explanation: CRITICAL crisis - possible suicidal ideation disguised as relapse. Keep visible, urgent peer response needed.

examples.content: This is frustrating. I've been clean for a year and my family still doesn't trust me.
examples.explanation: Processing family dynamics in recovery - normal discourse

examples.content: Meetings are just cult indoctrination. Wake up sheeple!
examples.explanation: Inflammatory but not attacking individuals - may generate discussion
